title: 107_hr3920
content: The "Rancher Preservation Act" is the short title of the Act. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include special requirements regarding the black-tailed prairie dog. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to require the use of the best scientific and commercial data available for determining the status of the black-tailed prairie dog. The Secretary must prioritize empirical or peer-reviewed data and include population numbers in the evaluation. The Secretary must use empirical or peer-reviewed data, including population numbers, to determine the status of the black-tailed prairie dog. Field data observation is required for this species, and data from landowners must be accepted. The Secretary must use empirical or peer-reviewed data, including population numbers, to determine the status of the black-tailed prairie dog. Data from landowners collected through observation of the species on the land must be acknowledged and included in the rulemaking record for any determination of the species as endangered or threatened. Independent scientific review requirements are defined in this subsection. The independent scientific review requirements define actions related to determining the status of the black-tailed prairie dog as an endangered or threatened species under section 4(a). The term 'qualified individual' refers to someone with expertise in biological sciences who has demonstrated scientific knowledge through peer-reviewed publications or other means. Qualified individuals in biological sciences must have demonstrated scientific expertise on the black-tailed prairie dog or a similar species relevant to the Secretary's decision, without any conflicts of interest. Qualified individuals in biological sciences must have demonstrated scientific expertise on the black-tailed prairie dog or a similar species relevant to the Secretary's decision, without any conflicts of interest. They should not have a direct financial interest or be employed by anyone with a financial interest opposing the action under consideration. The Secretary must appoint independent scientific reviewers who have no financial interest or employment ties to those opposing the action under consideration. Recommendations will be sought from the National Academy of Sciences to maintain a list of qualified reviewers for independent scientific review of actions. Before any final action, the Secretary must appoint 3 qualified individuals from a list for independent scientific review. The reviewers' selection and activities are not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary appoints 3 qualified individuals for independent scientific review. Reviewers are compensated and must provide their opinion on scientific information for the black-tailed prairie dog within 3 months. The Secretary appoints 3 qualified individuals for independent scientific review of relevant information on the black-tailed prairie dog within 3 months. Referees provide their opinion on taxonomy, population models, and ecological information. The Secretary evaluates the recommendations and includes a summary in the final determination. The Secretary evaluates the results of an independent scientific review on the black-tailed prairie dog, including a summary of the review and an explanation if the majority recommendation is not followed. The report of the peer reviewers is included in the official record of the proposed action. The report of peer reviewers on the black-tailed prairie dog is included in the official record of the proposed action for public review. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections in the Act. Special requirements regarding black-tailed prairie dog are included in the proposed action for public review.
